Evolution may be fact, considering how you look at it, but there is no testable evidence that shows the possibility of a species evolving into another species with the ability to reproduce. The closest thing is a hybrid which cannot reproduce.

post_info.post_title: What keeps the evolution-creation debate going?

Many hybrids can reproduce... this can be rare in some examples, but is very common in others.
 
 I suspect we'll now have the no true scotsman fallacy emerge, where reproducing hybrids' parent species are redefined as part of a single species..

Many hybrids can reproduce... this can be rare in some examples, but is very common in others.
 
 I suspect we'll now have the no true scotsman fallacy emerge, where reproducing hybrids' parent species are redefined as part of a single species..

 
 Care to name the hybrids which reproduce? And how did they become defined as hybrids? Is it because Man cross bred them with other animals to create the new hybrid species originally? If so, then that isn't an example of evolution at all but is another example of human genetic manipulation which led to the existence of hybrids. Therefore, to say that any of those hybrids which can reproduce are examples of one species evolving into another species is specious to the max. So as you can see, your shallow concern about a no true scotsman fallacy argument misses the mark all together.

One obvious example of a reproducing hybrid would be the granny smith apple, but I'm sure others can point out dozens if not hundreds of others.
 
 Granny Smith - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 My favourite animal is the liger, which can reproduce somewhat successfuly with its parent species. It doesn't usually form in the wild, but no real reason for that apart from the parents having different habitats.
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grizzly%E2%80%93polar_bear_hybrid
 
 here's a good one, grizzlies and polar bears, happen by themselves. Maybe we forced them together by global warming (sic)
 
 I mean the only way to ignore this is to retrospectively redefine what we mean by species when we find two things that cross boundaries. Feel free to define species however you want, its a pretty poorly defined term at the best of times, but I don't like going back and changing the definition afterwards.
 
 
that isn't an example of evolution 

 
 I'm not trying to give examples of evolution, I'm trying to give examples of reproducing hybrids and correct the incorrect but common belief that all hybrids are sterile.
